timeline.bodyText: I would call this QueryParser. I guess parser is more common for conversion from string to some object (its also the name used in Lucene).
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: Is the QueryNodeException helpful in diagnosing where the syntax error is, i.e. can it be converted to a meaningful error message shown to the user? If not, I would propose to catch it in the main body, change the return value to Optional<Query> and return an empty optional in case of a syntax error.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: It's considered bad practice to have an optional around a list. Just return an empty list, instead of an empty optional.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: I would add this directly as a constructor, or if you want to have a more descriptive name as a static ComplexSearchQuery fromTerms(Collection<Term> terms) method in ComplexSearchQuery. The builder pattern is only useful if you have a lot of possible constructor arguments, and want to create a nice interface for it. I actually think the builder interface is mostly outdated since IDEs are now intelligent enough to show named constructor arguments, e.g
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: Reuse converter here and in the other tests.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.bodyText: Please create a new expected complex search query, and test against this. For example, the current test also passes if searchQuery has a non-empty title because this field is not checked in this test.
timeline.author: tobiasdiez

timeline.message:
Remove Optional from Lists
Rename QueryConverter to QueryParser
Modify parser tests to compare complex queries
Make complex query construction from terms independent from normal building

Signed-off-by: Dominik Voigt <dominik.ingo.voigt@gmail.com>

timeline.author: koppor
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -26,7 +26,8 @@
      * @return a list of {@link BibEntry}, which are matched by the query (may be empty)
      */
     default List<BibEntry> performComplexSearch(ComplexSearchQuery complexSearchQuery) throws FetcherException {
-        // Default Implementation behaves like perform search using the default field as query
-        return performSearch(complexSearchQuery.getDefaultField().orElse(""));
+        // Default Implementation behaves like perform search using the default field phrases as query

timeline.author: koppor

timeline.bodyText:
NumberFormatException should be catched here.
See https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/Integer.html#valueOf(java.lang.String). I would use 0 and 9999 as default valuesto keep the search going.
timeline.author: koppor
